messageBody:
Hugh Ekeberg scripsit:

> I see your point but English is going to fragment anyway just as Latin
> did as Rome's empire faded. These processes are slow but inevitable.

Well, yes. But that time is centuries down the timeline, if it comes
at all. We are living in an unprecedented period of communication, and
while that doesn't stop dialect drift, it may prevent it from advancing
as far as unintelligibility. Nobody knows.

> I disagree about Literacy. Have another look at English
> itself, Shakespeare or Chaucer for example. Literacy like all art
> never fades, it's what human's do. We can't help but do it.

Eh? What humans do is speak and understand. Literacy, i.e. reading
and writing, isn't automatic at all. Only 10% of the languages spoken
today have a writing system.

> Then we have the computer generation with their texting shorthand. I
> bet you, texting shorthand will evolve the next standardized spelling
> over the next 100 years.

The evidence that texting is affecting orthography is literally nil.

--
There are three kinds of people in the world: John Cowan
those who can count, cowan@...
and those who can't.
